Paper 1.stem: In the diagram below, triangle ABC is congruent to triangle PNA. Given that $BC=22$ cm, $AP=32$ cm and angle $ACB=91^{\circ}$,
Paper 1.diagramDescription: Two triangles, ABC and PNA, are shown. Triangle ABC is on the left with a right-obtuse angle at C (91 degrees), and side BC labeled 22 cm. Triangle PNA is on the right, sharing vertex A with triangle ABC. A line segment connects B and N. Side AP is labeled 32 cm.

parts.questionText: calculate the length of BN,
calculate angle APN.

Paper 1.title: Congruent Triangles and Trigonometry

Paper 1.stem: P, Q and R are three points on level ground such that RPQ forms a right-angled triangle with PQ and RQ measuring 135 m and 205 m respectively. It is given that a building of height 50 m is situated at P and that the bearing of Q from P is 119°.
Paper 1.diagramDescription: A triangle RPQ on level ground with a North arrow at P. Angle RPQ is a right angle (90 degrees). The bearing of Q from P is marked as 119 degrees. Side PQ is 135 m and side RQ is 205 m.

parts.questionText: Calculate the bearing of R from Q.
Calculate the largest possible angle of depression from the top of the building to any point on the path RQ.

Paper 1.title: Bearings and 3D Trigonometry

Paper 1.stem: In triangle ABC, $AB=14.6$ cm, $BC=7.6$ cm and angle $BAC=31^{\circ}$.
Paper 1.diagramDescription: Triangle ABC with side AB=14.6, BC=7.6 and angle A=31 degrees.

parts.questionText: Find obtuse angle ACB.
Find the area of triangle ABC.

Paper 1.title: Trigonometry

Paper 1.stem: Three points A, B and C lie on a horizontal ground are such that $AB=24$ m and $BC=53$ m. Point B is due north of C. The bearing of A from B is 122°.
Paper 1.diagramDescription: Triangle ABC with point B positioned North of C. A line from C goes North to B. Side BC is 53m. Side AB is 24m. The angle at B, inside the triangle relative to the North line, can be deduced from the bearing.

parts.questionText: Find the distance AC.
Find the bearing of C from A.
Find the area of the triangular plot ABC.

Paper 1.title: Bearings and Triangle Area

Paper 1.stem: In the diagram, there are two right-angled triangles $\Delta ABD$ and $\Delta CEB$ such that $AD=12$ cm, $BD=15$ cm and $BE=20$ cm.
Paper 1.diagramDescription: Two right angled triangles. Triangle ABD with angle A = 90 deg. Triangle BCE with angle C = 90 deg. They are joined at B. Line DBE is a straight line.

parts.questionText: Find $\cos \angle ABD$.
If $\Delta ABD$ and $\Delta CEB$ are similar, find the length of BC.

Paper 1.title: Right-Angled Triangles Similarity

Paper 1.stem: In the diagram, a wooden ramp is shown where $\angle BCF=90^{\circ}$ and $\angle CBF=35^{\circ}$. ABCD, CDEF and ABFE are rectangles. $AB=40$ cm and $BC=75$ cm.
Paper 1.diagramDescription: 3D wedge/ramp shape. Base ABCD. Vertical face BCF (triangle). Slanted face ABFE.

parts.questionText: Find $\angle FAC$.

Paper 1.title: Angle in 3D Ramp

Paper 1.stem: A, B and C are three points on horizontal ground. The bearing of A from B is $040^{\circ}$. Angle ABC = $65^{\circ}$ is NOT explicitly stated but a North arrow at B is shown, line BA is drawn, and angle between North and BA is marked. Wait, diagram shows angle at A is 65 degrees. Text says bearing of A from B is 040.
Paper 1.diagramDescription: Triangle ABC. North line at B. Line BA makes 40 degrees with North. Angle at A is 65 degrees. Line BC extends to the right.

parts.questionText: Find the bearing of B from A.
Find the bearing of C from A.

Paper 1.title: Bearings

Paper 1.stem: In the triangle ABD, AC is perpendicular to BD. Angle $ADC=48^{\circ},$ $AC=8.4$ cm and $BC=5$ cm.
Paper 1.diagramDescription: Triangle ABD with altitude AC to base BD. AC=8.4, BC=5, Angle ADC=48.

parts.questionText: Calculate angle ABC.
Calculate AD.

Paper 1.title: Trigonometry in Triangles

Paper 1.stem: In triangle ABC, angle $ABC=90^{\circ},$ $BX=2XC$ and $\sin\angle AXC=\frac{3}{5}$.
Paper 1.diagramDescription: Right-angled triangle ABC with angle B=90. Point X is on BC. Line AX is drawn.

parts.questionText: Express as a fraction in its lowest terms, $\tan\angle AXB$.
Express as a fraction in its lowest terms, $\tan\angle ACB$.

Paper 1.title: Trigonometric Ratios

Paper 1.stem: In the triangle, $PQ=QR$, $PR=15$ cm and angle $PQR=90^{\circ}$.
Paper 1.diagramDescription: Isosceles right-angled triangle PQR with hypotenuse PR=15cm and right angle at Q.

parts.questionText: Calculate PQ.

Paper 1.title: Isosceles Right Triangle

Paper 1.stem: The diagram shows the positions of three towns, A, B and C. AB is 73 km, BC is 62 km and AC is 56 km. A is due North of C.
Paper 1.diagramDescription: Triangle ABC with side lengths AC=56, AB=73, BC=62. A is North of C, so AC is a vertical line.

parts.questionText: Calculate the bearing of B from A.
Calculate the area of triangle ABC.

Paper 1.title: Bearings and Triangle Area

Paper 1.stem: In the diagram ABC is a straight line, $BC=10$ cm, $CD=8$ cm and $BD=6$ cm.
Paper 1.diagramDescription: Triangle BCD where BC=10, BD=6, CD=8. ABC is a straight line extending from B to A.

parts.questionText: Explain why a circle that passes through B, C and D can be drawn in the above diagram. Give reasons for each step of your working.
Hence find the exact value of cos ABD.

Paper 1.title: Right-Angled Triangle and Trig

Paper 2.stem: The diagram shows a box in the shape of a cuboid measuring 15 cm by 8 cm by 10 cm. The box has an open lid such that I and J are vertically above the midpoints of DH and CG respectively. A rod is placed inside the box such that it touches the box only at A and J.
Paper 2.diagramDescription: Cuboid ABCDEFGH with lid IJKL (partially shown). Rod AJ is indicated.

parts.questionText: Find the length of BE.
Find the length of AG.
Show that the length of the rod, AJ, is 22.97 cm, correct to 4 significant figures.
Find angle JAG.

Paper 2.title: 3D Trigonometry

Paper 2.stem: A, B, C and D are points on horizontal ground. $AB=35$ m and $BC=68$ m. The bearing of B from A is $137^{\circ}$ and the bearing of C from B is $192^{\circ}$. Angle $ABD=85^{\circ}$ and angle $BCD=70^{\circ}$.
Paper 2.diagramDescription: Geometric diagram showing points A, B, C, D on a plane. North lines are drawn at A and B. Triangles ABC and DBC are formed.

parts.questionText: Show that angle $ABC=125^{\circ}$.
Calculate AC.
Calculate DC.
A man travels in a straight line from D to C. X is the position of the man where it is the shortest distance from B during this journey. Show that $BX=63.9$ m.
A drone is hovering vertically above B. The angle of elevation of the drone from C is $40.5^{\circ}$. Calculate the greatest angle of elevation of the drone from a point on DC.

Paper 2.title: Bearings and 3D Elevation

Paper 2.stem: The diagram shows three points, $A$, B and L on a horizontal field. $AL=37.5~m$, $AB=60$ m and angle $LAB=63^{\circ}$
Paper 2.diagramDescription: Triangle LAB. AL=37.5m, AB=60m, Angle LAB=63 degrees.

parts.questionText: Calculate LB.
Calculate angle LBA.
T is top of a vertical tree at L. The angle of elevation of the top of the tree seen from A is $10^{\circ}$. Find the height of the tree.
A bird is hovering at a height of 3 m above the field. It spots a prey on the ground at angle of depression of $60^{\circ}.$ Calculate the distance that the bird must fly to catch its prey.

Paper 2.title: Trigonometry Problems

Paper 2.stem: ABCD is a field on horizontal ground. $AD=163~m$, $BD=329~m$, $CD=152$ m and angle $BDC=48^{\circ}$. The bearing of B from A is $151^{\circ}$ and the bearing of D from A is $237^{\circ}$.
Paper 2.diagramDescription: Quadrilateral ABCD representing a field. North arrow at A. Angles and lengths given.

parts.questionText: Calculate the bearing of D from B.
Calculate the distance from B to C.
An aircraft is flying above D. Find the angle of elevation of the aircraft from C when it is 245 m vertically above D.

Paper 2.title: Bearings and Elevation

Paper 2.stem: In the diagram, XYZ is a straight line. $AY=20~m$, $AZ=12$ m and $YZ=16m$. The ratio of XY: YZ is 1: 4.
Paper 2.diagramDescription: Triangle AYZ with AZ=12, AY=20, YZ=16. Line extended from Y to X. XY is part of line XYZ.

parts.questionText: Prove that triangle AYZ is right-angled.
Find the value of $\cos \angle AYX$, giving your answer as a fraction in its lowest terms.

The area of triangle AXY is $24m^{2}$. Lenard says: In another triangle AYW, whereby the length $YW=YX$ and its area is the same as that of triangle AXY, it is possible for angle Y to be acute. Explain why Lenard is correct. Use calculations to support your answer.

Paper 2.title: Trigonometry and Triangle Area

Paper 2.stem: In the diagram, ABCDEFGH is a cuboid with dimensions 8 cm by 6 cm by 15 cm. V is the centre of the rectangular base.
Paper 2.diagramDescription: Cuboid ABCDEFGH. V is center of base ABCD.

parts.questionText: Show that $EV=15.8$ cm, correct to 3 significant figures.
Calculate angle ACE.
A pyramid EDAC is cut out from the cuboid. Find the remaining volume of the cuboid.

Paper 2.title: Cuboid 3D Geometry

Paper 2.stem: The points A, B, C, D and E are shown in the diagram below such that ABC and AED are straight lines and $BE=\sqrt{8}$ cm. E(4,3), A(-3,1), B(1,1), C(4,1).
Paper 2.diagramDescription: Two similar triangles ABE and ACD on coordinate axes.

parts.questionText: Without using a calculator, find sin ABE.
Without using a calculator, find cos ABE.
Using your answer in (a)(i) calculate the area of triangle ABE
Given that triangle ABE and triangle ACD are similar, calculate the area of triangle ACD.

Paper 2.title: Similar Triangles and Trig

Paper 2.stem: The diagram shows the positions of a harbour, H, a lighthouse, L, and two buoys P and Q. HPQ is a straight line. The bearing of P from H is $306^{\circ}$. $HP=3~km$, PL = 2.5 km and angle $HPL=124^{\circ}$
Paper 2.diagramDescription: Diagram with points H, P, L, Q. HPQ is a line. North arrow at H.

parts.questionText: Find the bearing of H from P.
Find the bearing of L from P.
A helicopter is 500 m vertically above P. Find the angle of elevation from L to the helicopter.
Calculate HL.

A ship sailed from the harbour along the line HPQ at an average speed of $4.5~m/s$. At 0809 hours, it reached a point X which is nearest to the lighthouse. Find the time it left the harbour. Correct your answer to the nearest minute.

Paper 2.title: Bearings and Distances

Paper 2.stem: In the diagram, PQRS is a vertical rectangular wall of height 2.5 m and length 7.5 m. T is a point on level ground from the base of the wall RS. $\angle STR=95^{\circ}$ and $\angle SRT=40^{\circ}$. X is a point on ST such that SX: XT is 1: 3.
Paper 2.diagramDescription: Rectangular wall PQRS. Triangle SRT on ground plane. X on ST. Angle STR=95, Angle SRT=40.

parts.questionText: Calculate the length of SX.
Calculate the length of XR.
Calculate the length of PT.
A bird sat on the ledge of the wall along PQ such that its angle of elevation from X is the largest. Find $\theta$.

Paper 2.title: 3D Trigonometry Wall

Paper 2.stem: The diagram above shows a park ABCD that is on horizontal ground, crossed by a straight path AC. Point B is due north of C. $AB=700~m$, $BC=550$ m and $CD=780~m$. Angle $ABC=115^{\circ}$ and angle $ACD=29^{\circ}$.
Paper 2.diagramDescription: Quadrilateral ABCD. B is North of C. Triangle ABC and ADC sharing side AC.

parts.questionText: Show that length $AC=1057.32$ m, correct to two decimal places.
Calculate the bearing of D from C.
Find the total area of the park ABCD. Correct your answer to the nearest whole number.
A vertical building is located at point D. The angle of elevation of the top of the building from point C is 10.9°. Find the height of the building.

Paper 2.title: Trigonometry and Bearings
